name: N-(4-decylphenyl)-4-methylbenzamide
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-2315
Reason: 4-decylphenyl and methyl substitutions generally lower the melting point compared to a phenyl group, as they reduce the molecular weight and steric hindrance. Each decyl group can lower the melting point by approximately -10°C due to reduced molecular weight and steric hindrance. The methyl group also contributes to a slight decrease in melting point due to its reduced molecular weight and van der Waals interactions, estimated at around -5°C. The presence of two phenyl groups can significantly increase the melting point due to their ability to enhance π-π interactions and overall molecular rigidity. Each phenyl group may contribute around +30 to +50°C.
